questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding slit-lamp examination are false?

1. It is a procedure done in a semi-dark room.

2. It can be used to measure the curvature of the central cornea.

3. It can view the fundus when used along with special lenses.

4. When used with a small diameter lens, the image formed is erect and virtual.
questions.solution:
Statements 2 and 4 are false.

Slit-lamp is not used to examine the posterior segment and measure the curvature of the central cornea. Keratometer is used to measure central corneal curvature so as to estimate corneal astigmatism. 

Slit-lamp biomicroscope is a semi-dark room procedure and uses the same principle as a compound microscope.

It is used to see the cornea and anterior segment and assess the position, depth, and size of any abnormalities present.

Special lenses should be used along with the slit lamp to view the fundus. The lenses along with the slit lamp are a small diameter lens, Hruby lens, modified Koeppe's lens, and Goldmann's three-mirror contact lens. Small diameter lens is the most commonly used technique to view the fundus and it produces an inverted, real, and magnified image (similar to an indirect ophthalmoscope).

questions.text: An elderly diabetic patient presented with complaints of blurring of vision. The patient's fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) image is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a diabetic patient with the blurring of vision and an FFA image showing a flower petal pattern (petaloid appearance) is suggestive of cystoid macular edema (CME). It occurs due to the accumulation of dye in the macular region.

CME is defined as a collection of fluid between the outer plexiform (Henle's layer) and an inner nuclear layer of the retina. This results in the formation of cyst-like cavities around the foveola. It occurs due to a break in the inner and outer blood-retinal barrier. Common causes of CME include uveitis, previous cataract surgery (Irvine-Gass syndrome), retinal vein occlusions, diabetic retinopathy, and retinitis pigmentosa.

Patients may complain of blurring, distortion, and micropsia. In clinically established cases, the macula will show a 'honeycomb' appearance on ophthalmoscopy due to multiple cystoid spaces. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) image shows intraretinal cystoid spaces and foveal depression. In advanced cases, a lamellar macular hole may develop. Treatment includes topical anti-prostaglandins (ketorolac), steroids, systemic carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (oral acetazolamide), and managing the causative factor. Given below is an OCT image showing intraretinal cystoid spaces in CME:

Other options:

Option A: Central serous retinopathy is the spontaneous serous detachment of the macular region neurosensory retina with/without retinal pigment epithelium detachment. Patients complain of sudden onset painless loss of vision, micropsia, and metamorphopsia. FFA shows two patterns of leakage, ink-blot pattern and smoke-stick pattern. OCT image of central serous retinopathy is seen below which neurosensory retinal detachment and accompanying small detachments of the retinal pigment epithelium.

Option B: Macular hole is a partial or full-thickness hole in the neurosensory retina of the foveal region. Causes include trauma, CME, or idiopathic. There is a decrease in vision, typically around 6/60 for full-thickness holes. FFA shows early foveal hyperfluorescene without a leak. OCT image of the macular hole is seen below which shows a full-thickness hole in the foveal retina.

Option D: Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is a bilateral disease affecting people who are above 50 years of age. It can be exudative or non-exudative types. There can be a gradual or sudden loss of vision depending on the type of AMD. Drusens (yellowish-white elevated spots caused by extracellular deposits in the macular region) of various types can be noted. FFA shows punctate hyperfluorescence due to the drusen. questions.text: A male patient comes with a history of diplopia and convergent squint of the right eye. You note that his head is tilted to the right for better vision. When asked to close his left eye and locate an object placed on his right side, he points it out farther right than it actually is. Forced duction test is negative. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation of diplopia, convergent squint, compensatory head posture, and false projection, along with a negative forced duction test suggests a likely diagnosis of paralytic strabismus. 

Paralytic squint can be caused by many etiological factors such as neurogenic lesions (involving the nucleus, nerve root, or peripheral nerve), myogenic lesions, or neuromuscular junction lesions (myasthenia gravis). 

Diplopia is the primary complaint in this condition. There may be associated nausea and vertigo due to diplopia. Signs include primary deviation, secondary deviation, compensatory head tilt, and false projection/orientation.

Primary deviation is the deviation of the affected eye and it will deviate away from the action of the affected muscle, e.g. Secondary deviation is the deviation of the normal eye when the patient fixates with the squinting eye. Compensatory head posture means that the head tilts toward the action of the paralyzed muscle. False projection/orientation occurs due to increased impulse conveyed to the paralyzed muscle. 

A forced duction test is done to differentiate between restrictive and paralytic squint. Apart from that, investigations done for all cases of strabismus (refractive error testing, cover test, etc) as well as diplopia charting, and Hess screen test should also be done.

Diplopia is treated by using an occluder on the affected eye.  Chemodenervation of the contralateral muscle using botulinum toxin and surgical treatment if there is no improvement after 6 months can also be done to manage the condition.

Other options:

Option A: Accomodative esotropia is a convergent squint that occurs as a result of overaction of convergence related to accommodation reflex. It is the most common type of squint present in children and develops around 2 - 3 years of age. 

Option C: Restrictive squint occurs when there is a restriction to extraocular movement rather than paralysis of extraocular muscles. It can be seen in conditions such as thyroid ophthalmopathy, entrapped inferior rectus muscle in blow-out fracture and orbital mass lesions. Forced duction test will be positive. 

Option D: Primary exotropia is a form of divergent squint and may be intermittent or constant. It is usually seen in children. The deviation can be precipitated by conditions such as bright light and ill-health.

questions.text: A patient comes with complaints of sudden onset loss of vision. However, the evaluation shows no abnormalities. Suspecting malingering, you test the patient using the device shown below. Which of the following findings is elicited by this test?
questions.solution:
To confirm malingering, you are looking for optokinetic nystagmus which is done using the optokinetic drum (above-shown device). 

Nystagmus is the rapid oscillatory eye movements that are involuntary and independent of normal eye movements. It can be divided into physiological and pathological nystagmus. 

Physiological nystagmus is nystagmus that occurs naturally in different situations. Optokinetic nystagmus is physiological jerk nystagmus that is induced by asking the patient to look at objects that are moving serially, such as the optokinetic drum. Here, the eyes will follow a fixed strip and then jerk back to reposition centrally to gaze at a new strip. This phenomenon can be used to rule out malingering.

Other options:

Option A: Physiological vestibular nystagmus is a jerk nystagmus that is produced by stimulating the tympanic membrane with hot/cold water. It is the basis of the caloric test. When cold water is poured on the right ear, patient will develop a left jerk nystagmus  (rapid phase towards the left) and the reverse happens with warm water.

Option C: Brun's nystagmus is a form of pathological nystagmus and occurs due to cerebello-pontine angle tumors. It produces a low frequency, high amplitude nystagmus when the patient looks towards the side of the lesion (gaze-evoked) and a high frequency, low amplitude nystagmus when the patient is looking away from the lesion (vestibular imbalance). 

Option D: Ataxic nystagmus is a form of pathological nystagmus commonly seen in internuclear ophthalmoplegia. The pathologic gaze-evoked nystagmus is either unilateral or asymmetric nystagmus of the abducting eye and adducting eye.

questions.text: You examine a patient who has come for a regular check-up. Clinically, you observe shining reflex to be present in the pupillary area. Which of the following features can be seen associated with this reflex?
questions.solution:
Shining reflex is seen in pseudophakia and iridodonesis can be seen associated with the reflex.

Pseudophakia refers to an aphakia (absence of lens from the pupillary area) that has been corrected with an intraocular lens implant (IOL).  Iridodonesis is the tremulousness (slight quivering) of the iris that can be demonstrated in aphakic and pseudophakic patients. Pupils are normally black in color, but throwing light to the pupillary area will show a shining reflex in pseudophakic patients.

Other signs of pseudophakia (with posterior chamber IOL) include: 

  • A surgical scar at the limbus
  • Deep anterior chamber 
  • Purkinje image test will show 4 images, whereas there are only 2 images in aphakia.

After allowing the pupil to dilate, a slit-lamp examination will confirm the presence of IOL. If the refractive error is mild, spectacles may be used for correction. If the error is large, LASIK or IOL exchange is required.  

Other options:

Option A: Keratic precipitates are proteinaceous cellular deposits seen in anterior uveitis. They are pathognomonic for the disease. 

Option C: Iridodialysis is the traumatic detachment of the iris from the root of the ciliary body, resulting in a D-shaped pupil.

Option D: Shallow anterior chamber is seen in hypermetropia.

questions.text: An elderly patient is admitted with uncontrolled sugars and complaints of eye pain, diplopia,  and black, foul-smelling nasal discharge. On examination, there is periorbital swelling as well as a necrotic mass with a typical black eschar eroding the nasal septum. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a patient with diabetic ketoacidosis presenting with eye pain, diplopia, and black foul-smelling discharge suggests a diagnosis of mucormycosis.

Mucormycosis (rhino-orbito-cerebral mucormycosis) is an aggressive fungal disease that tends to invade vessels causing ischemic necrosis. Immunocompromised and diabetic patients are at higher risk for this disease.

Patients present with diplopia, visual loss, periorbital swelling, and areas of necrosis with typical black eschars on the nasal septum, turbinates, the skin of eyelids, and mucosa of the palate. Complications like retinal vascular occlusion, multiple cranial palsies, and cerebrovascular occlusion can occur.

Treatment includes intravenous administration of amphotericin B and wide excision of necrotic tissues. Exenteration may be required if the patient is unresponsive to treatment.  

Other options:

Option A: Blastomycosis is caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis that presents as systemic pyrogranulomatous infection, but primarily affects the lungs. 

Option C: Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous conditiion caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis. It has 3 stage of presentation. They are atrophic stage (foul-smelling purulent nasal discharge), granulomatous stage (granulomatous nodules in nasal mucosa) and cicatricial stage (stenosis of nares, adhesions of naso- and oropharynx).

Option D: Rhinosporidiosis is a chronic granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi. Patients complain of blood tinged nasal discharge and present with a leafy,poypoidal mass which is very vascular and bleeds on touch.

questions.text:
Which among the following are based on applanation tonometry?

1. Goldmann tonometer

2. Tono-Pen

3. Perkins tonometer

4. Pneumatic tonometer
questions.solution:
Goldmann tonometer, tono-pen, Perkin's applanation tonometry, and pneumatic tonometer are all based on the principle of applanation tonometry. 

Tonometers are used to measure intraocular pressure. There are two types of tonometers. They are indentation and applanation tonometers.

Applanation tonometry is more accurate. The applanation tonometer measures the amount of force needed to applanate (flatten) a known corneal area based on the Imbert-Fick law. Goldmann tonometer, Tono-Pen, pneumatic tonometer, and Perkin's applanation tonometry uses the principle of applanation.

Indentation tonometry is based on the principle that a plunger will indent more on a soft eye than a hard eye. Schiotz tonometer is the most widely used tonometer as it is cheap and hand-held. However, it can give false readings if used in an eye with abnormal scleral rigidity.

questions.text: A mother brings her 1-week-old neonate with complaints of watery discharge from the eyes. On examination, vesicles can be seen on the eyelids and around the eyes. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of watery discharge and vesicles on the eyelids and around the eyes in a one-week-old baby suggests the likely diagnosis of herpes simplex ophthalmia neonatorum caused by the Herpes simplex virus. 

Ophthalmia neonatorum (also known as neonatal conjunctivitis), is inflammation of the conjunctiva that occurs in the first month of life. Any type of eye discharge during the first week of life needs to be investigated because tears are not secreted this early in life.

The most common etiological agents are Neisseria gonorrhea, Chlamydia trachomatis, Herpes simplex, Staphylococcus aureus, and chemical toxicity.

Below given table compares the different types of conjunctivitis. 

Type of conjunctivitis Timing of onset Discharge consistency
Herpes simplex conjunctivitis  1 - 2 weeks Watery
Chlaymdial conjunctivitis  1 - 3 weeks Mucopurulent
Gonococcal conjunctivitis  First week Hyperpurulent
Chemical conjunctivitis  First few days Watery
Staphylococcal(and other bacterial) conjunctivitis  End of the first week Purulent

Herpetic conjunctivitis can cause eyelid and periocular vesicles. Corneal examination is mandatory as it may show dendritic/geographical epithelial lesions.

Conjunctival scrapings can be sent for viral cultures. Also, using the Papanicolaou smear, eosinophilic intranuclear inclusion can be noted. It should be seen as a systemic condition and treated with high-dose intravenous aciclovir. It may be assosciated with complications such as encephalitis and early diagnosis of it essential to management.

Other options-

Option B: Neonatal inclusion conjunctivitis (chlamydial conjunctivitis) also occurs in the first few days of life. It can present with mucopurulent discharge and can even form pseudomembranes. Conjunctival scrapings are taken to confirm the diagnosis. It is treated using oral erythromycin as well as erythromycin/tetracycline ointment. 

Option C: Gonococcal conjunctivitis presents in the first week of life. The baby would have severe eyelid edema and purulent discharge. If allowed to progress, can rapidly cause corneal ulceration. It should be treated using third-generation cephalosporins.

Option D: Chemical conjunctivitis presents within the first few days of life, with watery discharge. It will not present with vesicles and does not need treatment other than artificial tears.

questions.text: A middle-aged man comes with complaints of marked ptosis.  Pupils are reactive on examination. You suspect it to be a case of isolated third nerve palsy. Which of the following conditions is known to commonly cause this presentation?
questions.solution:
One of the common causes of isolated third nerve palsy that presents with reactive pupils is diabetes mellitus. 

Diabetic oculomotor nerve palsy typically presents with ptosis and diplopia, and the pupillary function is often spared. The pupil is spared because diabetic microangiopathy involves the vasa nervorum. This causes ischemia of the nerve's main trunk ie. the inner fibers, and thus superficial pupillary fibers remain intact. Other microvascular diseases such as hypertension also commonly cause isolated third nerve palsy with reactive pupils. 

Other options:

Option A: Neuromyelitis optica is bilateral optic neuritis along with ascending myelitis, resulting in progressive quadriplegia. It is not associated with ocular palsies.

Option B: When posterior communicating artery aneurysm occurs at its junction with the internal carotid artery, it may lead to isolated third nerve palsy. The pupils are involved to an even greater extent than the extraocular muscles. This aneurysm compresses the blood vessels as well as the superficially located pupillary nerve fibers, thus affecting both functions. Aneurysms of the posterior communicating artery occurring at other locations will usually be assosciated with multiple cranial nerve palsies.

Option D: Subarachnoid hemorrhage may occur due to the sudden rupture of an aneurysm of the circle of Willis. It causes third nerve palsy and dilated pupils and is also associated with signs of meningeal irritation.

questions.text: A laborer gives a history of welding during work, without a face shield. He developed severe pain in his eyes and states that the pain is worse with bright lights. He closes his eyes on exposure to the bright light.  Which among the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above history of a welder who did not use a face shield and later presented with photophobia and blepharospasm suggests the likely diagnosis of photophthalmia.

It is caused by ultraviolet rays (especially 311 to 290 nm) and occurs due to desquamation of the epithelium leading to numerous erosions. There is a latent period of 4-5 hours between exposure and onset of symptoms. Usually, it occurs after exposure to naked arc light or to the bright flash of a short circuit. In snow blindness, the clinical features are the same, but it occurs due to UV light being reflected off a snow-covered surface. It is managed by cold compresses and lubricant drops, as well as bandaging both the eyes for a day to allow regeneration of the epithelium. 

Other options:

Option A: Photopsia is the complaint of bright flashes of light/ flickering light sensation perceived by the patient. It occurs due to pulling on vitreoretinal attachments which irritate the retina, e.g vitreous shrinkage.

Option C: Glare is the reduction in vision that occurs due to too much light shining directly or reflecting from a surface into the eye. There is difficulty in distinguishing objects from their background. It can be seen in early cataract, corneal edema, and post-refractive surgery patients.

Blepharospasm is the involuntarty and sustained closure of the eyelids and are of two types:

  • Essential blepharospasm (Option D) is a condition that occurs spontaneously and is insidious in onset. There is brief involuntary closure of both eyes leading to inability to open the lids.
  • Reflex blepharospasm is casued by a sensory stimulus and it will stop once the stimulus has been removed.

questions.text:
In which of the following conditions do contact lenses provide better optical results as compared to spectacles?

1. Corneal dystrophies

2. Regular astigmatism

3. High degree anisometropia

4. Keratoconus with irregular astigmatism
questions.solution:
Contact lens usage will provide better optical results as compared to spectacles in high degree anisometropia and keratoconus with irregular astigmatism.

Contact lenses are artificial devices that act as a substitute for the anterior surface of the cornea. Based on the material used, there are 3 types of contact lenses- hard lenses, rigid gas permeable lenses, and soft lenses. Of the three, soft lenses, made of HEMA (hydroxyethyl methacrylate) are the most commonly prescribed. 

Optically, they provide better results when compared to spectacles in:

  • High degree anisometropia with a difference greater than 4D (dioptre), produces aniseikonia. Contact lenses are preferred because corrective spectacles cannot achieve binocular vision in aniseikonia.
  • Irregular astigmatism associated with keratoconus. It can be corrected better using rigid contact lenses.
  • Superficial corneal irregularities can be better treated with rigid contact lenses as they provide a smoother and optically more regular surface (improve visual acuity).

Contact lenses have multiple therapeutic uses. They include providing pain relief in bullous keratopathy by using soft bandage lenses as it protects the exposed corneal nerve endings from the eyelid's shearing forces during blinking. It also temporarily preserves corneal integrity in case of a descematocoele by preventing perforation and encouraging healing.

Constant use can cause complications such as giant papillary conjunctivitis, superficial punctate keratitis, tight lens syndrome, and acute/chronic hypoxia. Treatment includes reducing contact lens wearing time and increasing oxygen permeability of the lens.

Contact lenses are contraindicated in patients with corneal dystrophies, chronic dacryocystitis, dry eye syndromes, and recurrent diseases like iridocyclitis.

  • Rigid gas permeable lenses/ semi soft lenses:
    • Made up of silicone acrylate and cellulose acetate butyrate (CAB)
  • Soft lenses:
    • Made up of HEMA (hydroxy ethyl methyl acrylate)

questions.text: A young male patient comes for an eye assessment before a driver's license application. He states that he has difficulty interpreting the traffic lights. The ophthalmologist assesses him using the following method. Which of the following tests is being used?
questions.solution:
The patient's history is suggestive of color blindness, and the test being used is the Farnsworth–Munsell 100-hue test. 

This test is a spectroscopic test (the patient arranges color chips in ascending order) and consists of 85 caps of different hues in four racks. The color vision is judged according to the error score, such that a greater error score means poorer color vision. It is the most sensitive test for both congenital and acquired color vision defects.

Color blindness is the inability to appreciate one or more of the 3 primary colors, i.e. red, green, blue. It can be congenital or acquired. Hereditary conditions can be classified into dyschromatopsia (color confusion) and achromatopsia (rod monochromatism).  

Other options:

Option A: City university color vision is a spectroscopic test where a central colored plate should be matched with the closest hue from the four surrounding colors present in 10 plates.

Option B: Ishihara's pseudoisochromatic chart is a type of pseudoisochromatic chart in which there are patterns of colored and grey dots.  It will show one pattern to the normal individuals and another to a person with defective color vision. This is the most commonly used test for color vision.The below image shows an Ishihara's chart.

 

Option D: Holmgren's wools test is a color vision test where the patient is asked to make color matches from a selection of colored wools. The below image shows the test.

 

Other color vision tests include Edridge-Green lantern test (naming colors shown by a lantern) and Farnsworth D15 hue discrimination test (similar to Farnsworth–Munsell 100-hue test, but only uses 15 hues).

questions.text: A teenager who is known to have AIDS, and is on rifabutin, comes for regular follow-up. On examination, you note the following. What is shown in the below image?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a hypopyon. Rifabutin can cause acute anterior uveitis which can present with a hypopyon.

Hypopyon is a purulent exudate composed of inflammatory cells that settle down in the lower part of the anterior chamber due to gravity. It is associated with corneal ulcers (e.g., bacterial or fungal keratitis), conditions causing anterior uveitis, or severe inflammation of the globe such as endophthalmitis.

An important point to note is that hypopyons are usually sterile collections, and form due to toxins and not the organisms themselves. They can develop rapidly but also get rapidly reabsorbed due to their sterile nature.

Other options:

Option B: Mooren ulcer is an autoimmune disorder that causes severe inflammatory ulcerative keratitis. It is otherwise known as chronic serpiginous or rodent ulcer. It causes severe pain and photophobia, as well as a peripheral ulcer that undermines the epithelium.

An image of the ulcer is shown below:

 

Option C: Staphyloma is the localized bulging of a weak/thin sclera or cornea. Staphyloma can be of different types, anterior staphyloma, intercalary staphyloma (limbal area), ciliary staphyloma, equatorial staphyloma, and posterior staphyloma. Common causes of ciliary staphyloma are end-stage primary/secondary glaucoma and the most common cause for posterior staphyloma is pathological myopia.  

Option D: Exposure keratopathy is the drying of the cornea that progresses into corneal ulceration. It is caused by an inability to close the eyes completely.

questions.text: A young male patient comes with complaints of sudden onset floaters without any blurring of vision. He recalls intermittent similar episodes over the last year. Slit-lamp examination shows a reddish mass in the vitreous. Abnormal fragile vessels can be noted on fundoscopy. What clinical feature is the patient presenting with?
questions.solution:
The history suggestive of recurrent vitreous hemorrhage in a young male and examination findings of a reddish mass in the vitreous with the presence of abnormal fragile vessels on fundoscopy suggests a diagnosis of Eales' disease. The patient is presenting with vitreous hemorrhage.

Mild vitreous hemorrhage presents as sudden onset floaters and a large vitreous hemorrhage causes sudden onset painless loss of vision.

Eale's disease is the idiopathic inflammation of the peripheral retinal veins. The etiology is unknown but it is thought to have some association with hypersensitivity to antitubercular proteins. It is seen most commonly in young Asian males in the age range of 20-30 years. There is recurrent vitreous hemorrhage that occurs due to retinal neovascularization. This can be seen as abnormal fragile vessels in the retina. It can progress to complications such as tractional retinal detachment and neovascular glaucoma. Steroid therapy is the mainstay of treatment. 

Slit-lamp examination will show the vitreous hemorrhage as a reddish mass in the vitreous. Ultrasonography is critical in cases of large vitreous hemorrhage and should be done to exclude underlying retinal tear/detachment.

Most hemorrhages only require conservative management with head elevation and bed rest. Vitrectomy is considered only if the hemorrhage is not absorbed within 3 months.

Other options:

Option A: Drusen are extracellular deposits found in between the retinal pigment epithelium and Brusch membrane. They are assosciated with age-related macular degeneration. 

Option B: Asteroid hyalosis is a degenerative process where calcium pyrophosphate particles accumulate within the vitreous gel. It is clinically seen as multiple yellow-white round opacities. It is more prevalent in patients above the age of 75.

Option D: Synchysis scintillians occurs due to chronic vitreous hemorrhage and is often present in a blind eye. There are cholesterol crystals that are derived from plasma cels or degraded erythrocytes. It is clinically seen as multiple flat golden brown refractile particles.

questions.text: A 21-year-old female patient who is known to have Bell's palsy presented with dryness in her left eye. Ocular examination reveals mild punctate epithelial defects and dryness of the cornea. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with clinical features of dry eye and unilateral facial nerve palsy likely has a diagnosis of exposure keratopathy. 

Exposure keratopathy is the drying of the cornea despite normally produced tears. It occurs due to incomplete eyelid closure, also known as lagophthalmos.

Lagophthalmos can be caused by conditions such as facial nerve palsy, parkinsonism (reduced muscle tone), lid scarring, and proptosis. 

Clinical features include dry eyes, symptoms and signs of mild punctate epithelial changes and epithelial breakdown. 

Treatment depends on whether the exposure is reversible or permanent. Reversible exposure can be treated with artificial tears and eye ointments. The eyelid can be taped closed at night or external barriers like bandage silicone hydrogel or scleral contact lenses can be used. Permanent exposure requires permanent tarsorrhaphy. For facial nerve palsy, a gold weight can be inserted into the upper eyelid.  

Other options: 

Option B - Neurotrophic keratopathy is the loss/reduction of corneal sensation that occurs due to loss of innervation by the trigeminal nerve. It may be due to stroke, trigeminal ganglion ablation for neuralgia, diabetes, etc. 

Option C - Mooren ulcer is an autoimmune disorder that results in progressive peripheral corneal ulceration. This is characterized by severe pain and the involvement of the superficial one-third of the corneal stroma.

Option D - Herpes simplex keratitis is caused by the Herpes simplex virus (HSV). The patient complains of ocular discomfort, photophobia, and decreased visual acuity. HSV can cause characteristic epithelial (dendritic/geographic) keratitis or disciform keratitis.

questions.text:
A student is referred by the school nurse with complaints of recurrent headaches and inability to read from the classroom board. There is no diplopia. Examination shows a refractive error of -1D in the right eye and an error of -3D in the left eye. What is your diagnosis?

D - dioptre
questions.solution:
The history of defective vision and 2 different refractive errors of the eyes suggests a diagnosis of anisometropia.

Anisometropia occurs when the total refraction of both eyes are unequal. A difference of 1D in the two eyes causes a 2% difference in the size of retinal images formed. A difference up to 2.5D is well-tolerated, but beyond 4D cannot be tolerated. Anisometropia can occur as a combination of emmetropia, myopia, hypermetropia, and astigmatism.

It is diagnosed after retinoscopic examination and autorefractometry. 

Treatment includes the usage of spectacles (it can be tolerated up to a maximum difference of 4D), contact lenses, intraocular lenses (for uniocular aphakia), refractive corneal surgery, or refractive lens exchange methods (used in high degree anisometropia).

Other options: 

Option B: Aniseikonia occurs when the images that are projected to the visual cortex are abnormally unequal in size. A high degree of anisometropia can also cause anisekonia. However, here the student has a refractive difference of only 2D.

Option C: Irregular astigmatism is the irregular change of refractive power that occur in different meridians. Patients complain of polyopia (seeing multiple images), distortion of objects and defective vision. It is assosciated with corneal irregularities and keratoconus.

Option D: Emmetropia is defined as an optically normal eye where the parallel rays of light coming from infinity focuses at the retina with accomodation at rest.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old girl complains of blurred vision despite using eyeglasses with a correction of -7D. On examination, you note that her eyes are prominent and her pupils are large. Which of the following clinical features may be seen in this condition?

D- diopters
questions.solution:
The history of a rapidly progressive refractive error and findings of prominent eyes with large pupils are suggestive of pathological myopia. Optic disc crescent can be seen in this condition.

Pathological myopia is otherwise known as degenerative/progressive myopia and starts during childhood. It results in high myopia, greater than -6D, by the time the children become adults.

Children complain of defective vision and with progressive degeneration, there will be uncorrectable loss of vision. High myopes often have prominent eyeballs with a deep anterior chamber and mildly large pupils which react sluggishly to light.

Fundus examination shows a characteristic myopic crescent at the optic disc. Other features that are seen are Foster-Fuchs' spot (due to sub-retinal neovascularization), lattice degeneration/snail track lesion, posterior staphyloma (ectasia of the sclera at the posterior pole), and posterior vitreous detachment due to vitreous degeneration.

Pathological myopia is optically treated with under-correction to avoid minification of the images. Contact lenses are preferred as they avoid peripheral distortion as well as the minification caused by strong concave spectacles.  

Other options:

Option A & B: Small optic disc and a shallow anterior chamber are seen in patients with hypermetropia.

Option C: Munson's sign is seen in keratoconus. There is a localized bulging of the lower eyelid that can be seen in a downward-looking eye.

  • Moderate myopia, when the error is between -3D to -6D.
  • High myopia, when the error is > –6D.

questions.text:
A patient comes with complaints of frequent changes in her presbyopic glasses. On gonioscopy, the anterior chamber angle appears normal. Perimetry shows a small wing-shaped paracentral scotoma. IOP is measured to be 23mmHg. What is the likely diagnosis?

IOP - Intraocular pressure
questions.solution:
A history of frequent changes of presbyopic glasses with an increased IOP and paracentral scotoma suggests a likely diagnosis of primary open-angle glaucoma.

Primary open-angle glaucoma/chronic simple glaucoma occurs due to reduced aqueous outflow facility which is caused by trabecular meshwork stiffening. It is characterized by open anterior chamber angle, characteristic optic disc cupping, specific visual field defects, and a slowly progressive increase of IOP.  

Symptoms such as new-onset headache/eye ache are present. However, patients most commonly present with frequent changes in presbyopic glasses.

The optic disc changes are progressive with an increasing cup: disc (C/D) ratio (normal is 0.3 to 0.4), nasal shifting of retinal vessels (Bayonetting sign), and finally resulting in glaucomatous optic atrophy where the optic disc appears excavated. Visual field defects, such as small wing-shaped paracentral scotoma, is the earliest clinically significant scotoma. 

Tonometry and central corneal thickness measurement should be done to correctly measure IOP. Normal IOP ranges from 11- 21mmHg. To rule out other glaucomas gonioscopy is done. Visual field defects are detected by perimetry.

Medical therapy such as prostaglandin analogs, topical beta-blockers, etc are used in treatment. Laser trabeculoplasty and trabeculotomy can be required if it is not managed medically.

Other options:

Option A: Primary angle-closure glaucoma occurs due to slow synechiae closure of the anterior chamber angle. Otherwise, other presentations are similar to open-angle glaucoma with optic disc cupping and visual field defects. 

Option C: Ocular hypertension is defined as a persistent increase of IOP without optic disc changes and visual field defects. 

Option D: Normal-tension glaucoma occurs when the IOP is normal and below 21mmHg, but there is typical glaucomatous change and visual field defects.

questions.text: A teenager comes with complaints of difficulty in seeing far away objects. You assess him using Snellen's chart. The maximum he is able to read with his left eye, at a distance of 6 meters, is the 18 meter line. What is his left eye vision recorded to be?
questions.solution:
His vision would be recorded as 6/18.

Snellen's chart is used to evaluate a patient's visual acuity. The visual acuity is recorded as a fraction with the numerator being the distance of the patient from the chart and the denominator being the smallest line of letters that is accurately read.

Here, the teenager is sitting at a distance of 6 meters from the chart (numerator) and the smallest line of letters he is able to read is the 18-meter line (denominator). Thus, the vision recorded would be 6/18. 

Visual acuity is the measurement of the eye's ability to discriminate between two points. Visual acuity tests such as Snellen's contain a series of letters that are arranged in lines, and each line has progressively decreasing sizes of letters. 

Each letter of the chart is designed to fit in a square, the sides of which are five times the breadth of the constituent line. At a given distance, each letter subtends an angle of 5 min at the eye's nodal point. 

The letters on the line at the top of Snellen's chart should be read clearly at a distance of 60 meters. Each subsequent line is read at 36, 24, 18, 12, 9, 6, and 5 meters, respectively. 

Testing is done by seating the patient at a distance of 6meters from Snellen's chart (at this distance the rays of light are almost parallel and the patient exerts minimum accommodation). Then the patient is asked to read the chart with each eye separately and the results are recorded.

questions.text: You are volunteering for the medical humanitarian service organization in Ghana. A patient comes with complaints of marked eye redness and pain. You note hemorrhages, as shown below. Which of the following organisms cause this condition?
questions.solution:
The above history of marked red-eye and pain along with hemorrhages, as shown in the image, is suggestive of acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis, which is caused by enterovirus 70 (picornavirus).

Enterovirus 70 is an RNA virus. This disease was an epidemic in the far East and Africa and was known as epidemic hemorrhagic conjunctivitis. 

Patients complain of marked pain, redness, photophobia, and watering. On examination, conjunctival congestion and subconjunctival hemorrhage, as well as periauricular lymphadenopathy, can be noted.

The disease is self-limiting, however, antibiotics may be given to prevent secondary infection. 

Other options:

Option B: Chlamydia trachomatis is the causative agent of adult inclusion conjunctivitis and trachoma. Trachoma is chronic keratoconjunctivitis that is characterized by a mix of follicular and papillary conjunctivitis, pannus formation, and cicatrization in later stages. Adult inclusion conjunctivitis is characterized by acute follicular conjunctivitis with mucopurulent discharge.

Option C: Herpes simplex type 1 causes herpetic conjunctivitis and is typically unilateral follicular conjunctivitis with/without vesicular lesions on the face and/or eyelids. Most patients show preauricular lymph node enlargement.

Option D: Moraxella axenfield causes angular bacterial conjunctivitis. These patients present with foamy-white discharge and redness near the angles of the eye.

questions.text: A man who regularly uses contact lenses comes with complaints of blurred vision and ocular pain. Examination shows radial keratoneuritis as seen below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above presentation of blurred vision and pain, along with the findings of a radial keratoneuritis and ring lesion (seen in the image), suggests a probable diagnosis of acanthamoeba keratitis. 

It is caused by Acanthamoeba spp which are free-living protozoa found in soil, freshwater, and the upper respiratory tract. Contact lens wearers are the most prone to this infection.

Patients complain of blurring of vision and pain is often disproportionate to examination. There are characteristic perineural infiltrates, otherwise known as radial keratoneuritis, are pathognomonic and can be seen during early infection. As the infiltrates grow, they gradually coalesce to form the typical ring abscess.

Staining of the corneal scraping using periodic acid-Schiff or calcofluor white as well as culture is done to diagnose the disease. 

Management includes topical amoebecides, analgesics for pain, as well as debridement of the involved epithelium. Therapeutic keratoplasty is done for resistant cases. 

 The below image shows a hypopyon and typical ring abscess of amebic keratitis.

 

Other options:

Option A: Staphylococcal keratitis usually presents as photophobia, blurred vision, mucopurulent discharge and focal and well-defined white/yellowish-white infiltrate. There are features of anterior uveitis with hypopyon and keratic precipitates.

Option B: Candidal keratitis would present as a typical yellow-white densely suppurative infiltrate. Features of anterior uveitis can also be seen here. 

Option C: Herpes simplex keratitis presents as ocular discomfort, photophobia, and decreased visual acuity. HSV can cause characteristic epithelial (dendritic/geographic) keratitis or disciform keratitis.

questions.text:
Which of the following structures are a part of the anterior segment of the eye?

1. Choroid

2. Iris

3. Lens

4. Vitreous humor
questions.solution:
Iris and lens are a part of the anterior segment of the eye.

The eyeball is divided into 2 segments (anterior and posterior) by the lens. The structures anterior to the lens (including the lens) are classified as the anterior segment and the structures posterior to the lens are classified as the posterior segment.

The anterior segment is further divided by the iris into 2 chambers (anterior and posterior). The structures anterior to the iris, up to the cornea, make up the anterior chamber. The posterior chamber refers to structures posterior to the iris, up to the lens. 

In a nutshell, the anterior segment contains the following structures:

  • Cornea, iris, lens
  • The anterior and posterior chambers are connected via the pupil and contain aqueous humor

The posterior segment is made of structures posterior to the lens. Vitreous humor and choroid are part of the posterior segment. The posterior segment contains the following structures:

  • Retina, choroid, optic disc
  • The posterior chamber is filled with vitreous humor

questions.text: A patient comes with complaints of drooping of their right eyelid and reduced sweating of the face on the same side. In this condition, which of the following is also likely to be seen on examination?
questions.solution:
The patient's history of drooping of the right eyelid and reduced sweating is suggestive of Horner's syndrome and right eye miosis is also likely to be seen on examination.

Horner's syndrome (otherwise known as oculosympathetic palsy) is a triad of miosis (causes anisocoria in most cases as presentation is unilateral) with ipsilateral ptosis and anhidrosis. 

Horner's syndrome can be caused by brainstem stroke, carotid dissection, and tumors impinging on the sympathetic chain, but most of the time, it is idiopathic and unilateral. When painful Horner's syndrome occurs, especially acute in onset, carotid dissection should be suspected. 

Apraclonidine test is used to confirm the diagnosis where instillation of the drops causes reversal of ptosis and miosis. Fasanella Servat operation is used to treat ptosis in Horner's syndrome.

questions.text: A healthy 22-year-old lady presents to the casualty with sudden onset loss of vision and pain in her right eye for the past 2 days.  Fundal examination is normal, but when light is shone on the pupils, there is an ill-sustained constriction to light. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's history of sudden onset loss of vision with a normal fundus and Marcus Gunn pupil suggests the diagnosis of retrobulbar neuritis.

Retrobulbar neuritis is a type of optic neuritis which involves the optic nerve behind the eyeball. The fundus appears normal in majority of the cases. Marcus Gunn pupil (ill-sustained constriction to light) can be seen and it is elicited using the swinging flashlight test. Color vision is also impaired.

Investigations include MRI brain and orbit to rule out multiple sclerosis as retrobulbar neuritis is often one of its earliest symptoms. Multifocal VEP is also useful for diagnosis. The condition is managed by treating causes and corticosterid therapy (intravenous methylprednisolone in case of multiple sclerosis).

Option B: Argyll Robertson pupil occurs due to neurosyphilis and requires syphilis serology testing. Serology testing is the mainstay of investigation. Neurosyphilis is ruled out by a lumbar puncture. 

Option C: Amblyopia is the partial and reversible loss of vision for which no cause is found on ocular physical examination. It can occur due to strabismus, stimulus deprivation, anisometropia, etc. 

Option D: Papillitis is a type of optic neuritis where the optic disc is involved. Marcus Gunn pupil is also present in this case, however, on fundus examination, there would be characteristic disc hyperemia and blurring of the margins. The retinal veins are congested and splinter hemorrhages as well as fine exudates can be seen on the optic disc.

Attached below is the image showing the swinging flashlight test as well as the explanation:

 

It is elicited as explained below:

A flashlight is shone at the normal eye. When the normal eye is stimulated, both pupils constrict. The flashlight is then swung to the diseased eye. This causes both the pupils to dilate.

Normally, when the input from both optic nerves to the Edinger-Westphal nucleus is the same, the pupil to which light is being transferred remains constricted due to consensual light reflex.

However, with a diseased optic nerve, the input from the diseased side is reduced. Hence, when light is transferred to the diseased eye, both the pupils will dilate. And on swinging the light back to the normal eye, both pupils will constrict again.  This 'escape dilatation' is known as a relative afferent pupillary defect/Marcus Gunn pupil.

questions.text: A  post-cataract surgery patient presents on the second day with ocular pain and circumcorneal congestion. Fundus examination is impaired and swinging flash-light test shows Marcus Gunn pupil. Which of the following would be key to managing this condition?
questions.solution:
The patient is suspected to have acute postoperative endophthalmitis and the key management is intravitreal antibiotics. It is a postoperative complication that occurs within 7 days of cataract surgery. 

The most likely cause would be contamination with bacteria such as Staphylococcus epidermidis, which is the most common.

The patient complains of pain, redness, and visual loss. Marked circumcorneal injection, hypopyon, Marcus Gunn pupil, and corneal haze can be noted.

Vitreous sampling is done to find the etiology.

The key to management is intravitreal antibiotics. Antibiotics such as ceftazidime and vancomycin are the treatment of choice.  

Other options:

Option A. Topical antibiotics are of limited benefit in endophthalmitis.

Option B. Nd:YAG laser is indicated in posterior capsular opacification (after cataract).

Option C. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors are indicated in cystoid macular edema. Cystoid macular edema is an uncommon post-cataract complication.

Related Pearl: Complications of cataract surgery

Occurs within the first few days to 4 weeks.

  • Endophthalmitis
  • Retained lens matter
  • Corneal edema
  • Wound leak and dehiscence
  • Toxic anterior segment syndrome

Late postoperative complications

Occurs within months to years.

  • Posterior capsule opacification (most common)
  • Cystoid macular edema
  • Secondary glaucoma
  • Retinal detachment
  • Intraocular lens malpositions:
    • Windshield wiper syndrome— intraocular lens haptic rubs on the endothelium
    • Sunset syndrome—inferior subluxation
    • Sunrise syndrome—superior subluxation
    • Complete dislocation of the intraocular lens.

questions.text: A male patient presented with painless, hard swelling of the lower eyelid that has been progressing in size. Examination revealed the following finding. What is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presentation of a progressive, hard, painless swelling is due to a probable diagnosis of chalazion.

Chalazion is a chronic and non-infective lipogranulamatous lesion that arises from the Meibomian glands (otherwise known as tarsal/meibomian cyst). It is the most common lid swelling seen.

A very small, soft, and recent chalazion only requires conservative management with hot compresses and topical antibiotic drops. Incision and curettage is the more conventional method of managing a chalazion. The contents are curetted out using a chalazion scoop. Intralesional steroids such as triamcinolone are preferred for chalazions which are located where the risk of surgical damage is greater (near structures such as lacrimal punctum).

A chalazion may become infected and form a hordeolum internum. Also, a recurrently forming chalazion should be biopsied to rule out meibomian gland adenocarcinoma (a form of sebaceous cell carcinoma).

Other options: 

Option A: Hordeolum externum is the suppurative inflammation of the gland of Zeis. It is hard and painful, and there is a visible pus point on the lid margin.

questions.text:
Arrange the following stages of xerophthalmia in the correct order of progression, according to WHO grading.

1. Conjunctival xerosis

2. Keratomalacia

3. Corneal xerosis

4. Corneal scar

5. Bitot's spot
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of stages of xerophthalmia is 1 - 5 - 3 - 2 - 4.

Xerophthalmia is a term used to cover all ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency. According to WHO grading, the order of progression is as follows:

  • XN: Night blindness
  • X1A: Conjunctival xerosis
  • X1B: Bitot's spot
  • X2: Corneal xerosis
  • X3A: Keratomalacia affecting less than 1/3rd of the corneal surface
  • X3B: Keratomalacia affecting greater than 1/3rd of the corneal surface
  • XS: Corneal scar
  • XF: Xerophthalmic fundus

Treatment includes local ocular therapy, vitamin A therapy, and treatment of underlying general disease.

Vitamin A therapy is given as:

  • All patients who are older than 1 year (except the reproductive age group of women) should be given 200,000 lU of vitamin A orally or 100,000 IU intramuscularly immediately on diagnosis, and then repeated the following day and 4 weeks later.
  • Children who weigh less than 8kg or are under the age of 1 year should be treated with half the dose (100,000IU).
  • In women of the reproductive age group, the stages of XN to X1B are treated with 10,000 IU daily for 2 weeks. In stages of corneal xerophthalmia (X3 and above), a full dose of 200,000 IU is given orally.

Related Pearl: WHO grading of Vitamin A deficiency

The term xerophthalmia is reserved to cover all the ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency.

X1A Conjunctival Xerosis Conjunctival epithelial alteration, loss of goblet cells
X1B Bitot’s spots Conjunctival keratinization and plaque formation
X2 Corneal xerosis Corneal epithelial alteration
X3A Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting <1/3rd of the corneal surface Liquefaction of corneal stroma
X3B Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting >1/3rd of the corneal surface              -
XS Corneal scar              -
XF Xerophthalmic fundus Degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium

 

The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia.

The first sign of xerophthalmia is conjunctival xerosis.

The pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia is the appearance of Bitot's spots.

Note:

Up to Stage X2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements. Active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient came with complaints of excessive lacrimation. Ocular examination showed an abnormality similar to what is shown below. Which of the following organism is likely to cause this condition?
questions.solution:
The above image shows Herbert's pits. This finding is seen in trachoma, which is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis, more specifically the trachoma inclusion conjunctivitis (TRIC) serovars A, B, Ba, C. 

Trachoma is a form of chronic infective conjunctivitis and is one of the leading causes of blindness. It has an ‘active’ inflammatory stage and a ‘cicatricial’ chronic stage.

The active inflammatory stage is more prevalent in children and presents with nonspecific symptoms of ocular irritation, foreign body sensation, and discharge (often mild symptoms). Examination findings at this stage show: 

  • Conjunctival follicles contain Leber cells (multinucleated lymphocytes)
  • corneal Herbert's follicles (similar to conjunctival follicles)

Cicatricial chronic stage is seen in middle age. And when the chronic infection with sequelae sets in, the patient complains of pain, lacrimation, photophobia, and later blurring, and finally loss of vision. Conjunctiva shows concretions (whitish deposits of inspissated mucus in depressions called glands of Henle). Corneal signs include: 

  • Herbert pits (pitted scars in the limbal which are remnants of healed Herbert follicles)
  • corneal opacity is seen in later stages.

There can be associated trichiasis ( when at least one eyelash rubs the eyeball) and entropion.

At present WHO grading with 'FISTO' is in use.

Trachoma is treated according to the WHO classification using the SAFE strategy (Surgery, Antibiotics, Facial hygiene, and Environmental improvement). Azithromycin is the antibiotic of choice, and surgery involves the correction of trichiasis and entropion. In case of significant corneal scarring, penetrating keratoplasty is done.

Related Pearl: WHO classification of trachoma (FISTO)

WHO grading of trachoma

  • TF = trachomatous inflammation (follicular): five or more follicles (>0.5 mm) on the superior tarsal conjunctiva.
  • TI = trachomatous inflammation (intense): diffuse involvement of the tarsal conjunctiva, obscuring 50% or more of the normal deep tarsal vessels; papillae are present
  • TS = trachomatous conjunctival scarring: easily visible fibrous white tarsal bands
  • TT = trachomatous trichiasis: at least one lash touching the globe
  • CO = corneal opacity sufficient to blur details of at least part of the pupillary margin

Related Pearl: WHO Programme to Control Trachoma: SAFE Strategy

  • S—Surgery: Trichiasis and entropion correction surgery → 3° prevention.
  • A—Antibiotics: Oral azithromycin, topical 1% tetracycline, topical 1% azithromycin → 2° prevention
  • F—Facial hygiene → 1° prevention.
  • E—Environmental cleanliness → primordial prevention

The strategy depends on the prevalence of trachoma follicle in children (aged 1–9 yrs)

  • >10% → Mass antibiotic treatment at the community level and FE measures
  • 5 to 10% → Targeted antibiotic treatment (affected families) and FE measures
  • < 5% → FE measures

questions.text: A 60-year-old man came to you with a white growth over the cornea, as shown in the image. Which of the following features can be seen associated with it?
questions.solution:
The given image shows pterygium. Stocker's line can be seen associated with a pterygium. It is a linear deposition of iron seen in the corneal epithelium, anterior to the head of a pterygium.

Pterygium is a wing-shaped, triangular fibrovascular ingrowth of degenerative conjunctival tissue that can encroach onto the cornea. It occurs as a response to prolonged exposure to ultraviolet rays, dry heat, etc.

It has 3 parts, a head (apical part on the cornea), a body (the part between the limbus and canthus), and a cap (semilunar white infiltrate in front of the head).

Patients may complain of irritation and grittiness due to localized drying effects. If the pterygium encroaches onto the pupillary area, it may interfere with vision and also induce astigmatism.

This condition can be treated symptomatically with tear substitutes for dry eye symptoms, and patients are advised to avoid ultraviolet rays. Surgical excision with free conjunctival limbal autograft is the preferred treatment to avoid recurrence. 

Other options:

Option B: Concretions are tiny cysts containing deposits of epithelial debris and may occur due to old age or in association with trachoma. 

Option C: Arcus senilis is an annular lipid infiltration in the peripheral cornea. It is an age age-related change that usually occurs bilaterally.

Option D: Busacca nodules are iris nodules seen in anterior uveitis.

questions.text:
Match the following types of cataracts with the conditions they are seen in.
1. Sunflower cataract a. Diabetes mellitus
2. Christmas tree cataract b. Atopic dermatitis
3. Shield-like cataract c. Myotonic dystrophy
4. Snowflake cataract d. Wilson's disease
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1 - d, 2 - c, 3 - b, and 4 - a.

Sunflower cataract is associated with Wilson's disease and shows yellowish-brown dots due to the deposition of copper.  

A diabetic cataract is typically seen as a snowflake/snowstorm appearance. It occurs due to the accumulation of sorbitol (because of hyperglycemia) resulting in osmotic overhydration of the lens. There is a development of cortical fluid vacuoles which later change into opacities. These opacities are shaped like a snowflake.

Christmas tree cataract is associated with myotonic dystrophy. They are fine iridescent cortical opacities that resemble a Christmas tree.

A shield-like cataract is seen in atopic dermatitis. Characteristically, there is a shield-like and dense anterior subcapsular plaque. It crinkles the anterior capsule of the lens and occurs bilaterally.

Match the following fundal findings with their associated diseases.

2. Splashed tomato appearance b. Central retinal vein occlusion

2. Splashed tomato appearance b. Central retinal vein occlusion

Toxoplasmosis can cause severe vitritis. This leads to an impaired fundus examination that will give a "headlight in fog" appearance (a white retinal inflammatory nidus when viewed through vitritis). This finding is seen in the image below:

Fundal examination may show a satellite lesion (a single focus of fluffy white retinitis that is associated with a pigmented scar) or vitiritis as mentioned above. Optic disc edema is also common.

Splashed tomato appearance of fundus is seen in central retinal vein occlusion and occurs due to massive retinal hemorrhages. It is seen in the image below:

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient comes with complaints of blurring of vision. You note the left eye is hypochromic and there are numerous stellate keratic precipitates present. Which of the following features does not correlate with this condition?
questions.solution:
The features of heterochromia iridis and fine stellate keratic precipitates are seen in Fuch's heterochromic iridocyclitis (FHI) and white pupillary reflex does not correlate with this condition.

Fuchs heterochromic iridocyclitis is a chronic, non-granulomatous anterior uveitis, that is usually unilateral. It is normally seen in middle-aged people who may complain of symptoms such as blurring of vision and persistent floaters.

Heterochromia iridis (the affected eye is hypochromic/hyperchromic) is noted in FHI. Rubeosis iridis and posterior subcapsular cataract are also fairly common findings.

On examination, stellate keratic precipitates known as endothelial dusting are seen. Tiny crystals (Russell bodies) and iris nodules (Koeppe nodules)  may also be found on the iris surface. Iris atrophy which appears as a smooth-looking iris can also be seen. 

Long-term monitoring is indicated to detect glaucoma and other complications. 

The below image shows an example of heterochromia iridis (the left eye is hypochromic when compared to the right eye).

 

Other options:

Option A: White pupillary reflex/leucocoria is commonly seen in conditions such as retinoblastoma, congenital cataract, retinpathy of prematurity, etc.

questions.text: A patient has been referred to you after detecting low blood ceruloplasmin levels. You note the following on examination.  In this disease, where is the copper deposited?
questions.solution:
The image shows Kayser–Fleischer ring, a brownish-yellow area of copper deposition that is present in the peripheral Descemet membrane. This is seen in Wilson's disease (hepatolenticular degeneration) and occurs due to a deficiency of ceruloplasmin. This leads to the abnormal deposition of copper in various tissues. 

The ring is best seen on gonioscopy.

Penicillamine therapy may cause the ring to disappear.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought with complaints of night blindness.  The mother notes that the child's father also has similar complaints. Fundus examination reveals the below image. Which of the following investigation needs to be done?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and fundal image are suggestive of retinitis pigmentosa (RP). Electroretinogram (ERG) is the investigation that needs to be performed in this case.

RP is a retinal degenerative disease that is initially predominant among rod photoreceptors and later spreads to cones (rod-cone dystrophy). It is the most common form of hereditary fundus dystrophy. It may occur as a sporadic disorder, or in an inherited form. Autosomal dominant type is the most common form of inheritance.

Nyctalopia and dark adaptation difficulties are frequently presenting symptoms, but peripheral visual problems may be noticed. The classic triad of clinical findings are:

  1. Bone-spicule retinal pigmentation
  2. Arteriolar attenuation
  3. ‘Waxy’ disc pallor

A posterior subcapsular cataract is a complication of this condition that is commonly seen in all of its subtypes.

Full-field ERG is a sensitive diagnostic test. Initially, it shows reduced scotopic rod and combined responses. With progression, the photopic responses reduce and eventually the ERG becomes extinguished.

Other options:

Option A: 20 Δ base-out prism test is used to test for binocular fusion in infants without manifest squint.

Option B: Hess chart is plotted to help in the diagnosis and monitoring of a patient with strabismus.

Option C: Cover-uncover test is used to test for the presence and type of heterophoria.

questions.text:
A 2-month-old baby is brought with complaints of excessive watering of the eyes, and photophobia. On examination, you note buphthalmos. IOP is measured to be 30mm of Hg. What is the likely diagnosis?

IOP - Intraocular pressure
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of excessive watering, photophobia, and buphthalmos, as well as increased IOP suggests a likely diagnosis of congenital glaucoma.

Primary congenital glaucoma (PCG) can be classified as:

  • True congenital glaucoma - IOP is elevated during intrauterine life.
  • Infantile glaucoma - manifests before 3 years of age.
  • Juvenile glaucoma (least common) -  IOP rises between 3 and 16 years of age.

Clinically, the child may present with buphthalmos. This refers to a large eye that results from stretching due to raised IOP before 3 years of age. The thin sclera appears blue due to underlying uveal tissue. Haab striae (curvilinear healed breaks in Descemet's membrane) and corneal haze (due to diffuse edema secondary to raised IOP) may also be noted on examination. Severe cases may also result in corneal scarring.

Evaluation is done under general anesthesia. Initially, IOP measurement is performed (10–12 mmHg is normal). A corneal diameter measuring greater than 12 mm is highly suggestive for an infant under the age of 1 year.

Management is essentially surgical and goniotomy and/or trabeculotomy may be done. 

Other options:

Option A: Retinoblastoma is the most common primary intraocular childhood tumor and presents within 1 - 2 years of age (depending on whether it is bilateral/unilateral). The most common clinical features noted are leukocoria (white pupillary reflex) and strabismus. Secondary glaucoma is a rare complication that may occur if tumor seeding invades the trabeculum.

Option C: Congenital hereditary endothelial dystrophy is a rare dystrophy that causes visual impairment and corneal clouding. It is due to focal/diffuse thickening of Descemet membrane and endothelial degeneration.  

Option D: Ehlers–Danlos syndrome type VI (ocular sclerotic form) is an inherited disease of impaired collagen formation. Ocular manifestations of this condition include blue sclera, scleral fragility (mild trauma could cause globe rupture), epicanthic folds, microcornea, keratoconus, keratoglobus, ectopia lentis, myopia, and retinal detachment.

questions.text: A mother brings her son to the outpatient department after noticing a convergent squint. She recalls that the child's uncle had undergone chemotherapy when he was young. The examination findings are shown in the image given below. Ultrasound shows a small tumor away from the foveola. Which of the following drugs are used in its management?
questions.solution:
The above image shows features of leukocoria and strabismus, which are seen in retinoblastoma. Vincristine, carboplatin, and etoposide are used in its management.

Retinoblastoma is the most common primary intraocular malignancy of childhood and arises from the neurosensory retina. It is associated with germline RB1 mutations, and heritable retinoblastoma patients are predisposed to non-ocular tumors (pinealoblastoma, osteosarcoma, soft tissue sarcoma, and melanoma).

Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes are characteristic histopathological features.

The most common presentations are leukocoria (white pupillary reflex/ amaurotic cat's eye appearance) and strabismus. Fundus examination is therefore mandatory in all cases of childhood squint.

Chemotherapy is the mainstay of treatment and comprises intravenous vincristine, carboplatin, and etoposide. It is given along with focal treatment such as brachytherapy.

Enucleation is indicated when

  • Tumor involves more than half of the retina.
  • The optic nerve is involved.
  • Glaucoma is present, and the anterior chamber is involved

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text: A woman complains of sudden-onset pain in the right eye that is worse at night, along with redness and a decrease in vision. Slit-lamp examination findings are shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis is anterior uveitis. The image shows keratic precipitates in the cornea, which is a feature of acute anterior uveitis. The clinical history of unilateral eye pain that is worse at night is typically seen in this condition.

Keratic precipitates (KP) are deposits on the corneal endothelium and are composed of lymphocytes, plasma cells, and macrophages. These precipitates are pathognomonic for anterior uveitis. 

Anterior uveitis is the inflammation of the uvea extending from the iris to the pars plicata.  

Inflammation leads to pseudo-rubeosis iridis (dilatation of the blood vessels) and exudation. A large amount of exudation causes the iris to become waterlogged with the sticky fluid and causes movement restriction. This is why there are sluggish pupillary reactions. The extravasated fluid is also an irritant that causes the ciliary muscle fibers to contract, leading to pupillary constriction.

The iris loses its clear and defined pattern and becomes "muddy." The exudate also spills into the anterior chamber. This causes the aqueous to become turbid and is seen as a hazy, milky "flare" on slit-lamp examination. This is known as aqueous flare and is the earliest sign of anterior uveitis. Other characteristic clinical features are Koeppe and Busacca nodules (iris nodules)and the formation of posterior synechiae.

Other options:

Options A and C: Acute congestive glaucoma and acute conjunctivitis are both differential diagnoses for acute anterior uveitis. However, they do not have the characteristic feature of keratic precipitates.

Option D: Concussion cataract occurs due to aqueous imbibition and injury of lens fibers during ocular trauma.

questions.text: A man comes with complaints of defective vision. On ophthalmoscopy, you note deep and wide cupped optic disc with nasal shift of blood vessels. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A history of defective vision and an ophthalmoscopic finding of deep and wide-cupped optic disc with nasal shift of blood vessels suggests a likely diagnosis of glaucomatous optic atrophy.

Optic atrophy is the degeneration of the optic nerve. Ophthalmoscopically, optic atrophy can be divided into five:

  • Glaucomatous optic atrophy shows the above-mentioned deep and wide-cupped optic disc with blood vessels shifted to the nasal side. It occurs due to long-standing raised intraocular pressure.
  • Primary optic atrophy shows a chalky white disc and well-demarcated margins. It is caused by a lesion proximal to the optic disc without papilloedema, e.g. multiple sclerosis, retrobulbar neuritis. 
  • Consecutive optic atrophy shows a yellow waxy disc. The edges are less demarcated and retinal vessels seem attenuated. It occurs secondary to degenerative/inflammatory lesion of the choroid or retina, e.g. chorioretinitis, pathological myopia, retinitis pigmentosa.
  • Post-neuritic optic atrophy gives a dirty-white colored optic disc, and the edges are blurred.  It develops after long-standing papillitis/papilloedema.
  • Vascular optic atrophy shows a pale optic disc with marked attenuation of the retinal vessels. It is caused by any condition that causes disc ischemia (other than glaucoma) e.g severe anemia, severe hemorrohage.

The underlying cause of optic atrophy should be treated. However, once the patient has complete optic atrophy, vision cannot be recovered.

Related Pearl: Classification of optic atrophy

  • Simple optic atrophy: (Primary) Image below
    • Pathology lies in portion of optic nerve behind lamina cribrosa.
    • Causes are multiple sclerosis, neurosyphilis, and traumatic optic neuropathy.
    • Well defined disc margin and chalky white in color.

Post-neuritic optic atrophy: (Secondary)

  • Occurs after disc edema.
  • Causes are Papillitis and papilledema
  • Blurred disc margin and dirty white in color
  • Consecutive optic atrophy
    • Extensive pathology of retina.
    • Causes are retinitis pigmentosa and any cause of diffuse chorioretinitis
    • Well defined disc margin and pale waxy disc.
  • Glaucomatous optic atrophy/Cavernous optic atrophy:
    • 100% cupping
    • Bayonetting of vessels
    • Laminar dot sign

questions.text:
Match the following findings of keratoconus with its method of detection.
1. Scissor reflex a. Slit-lamp examination
2. Munson's sign b. Physical examination
3. Oil droplet reflex c. Distant direct ophthalmoscopy
4. Vogt striae d. Retinoscopy
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1- d, 2 - b, 3 - c, and 4 - a.

1. Scissor reflex d. Retinoscopy
2. Munson's sign b. Physical examination
 3. Oil droplet reflex c. Distant direct ophthalmoscopy
4. Vogt striae a. Slit-lamp examination
  • Munson's sign is the localised bulging of the lower eyelid when the patient is looking downwards.
  • Using distant direct ophthalmoscopy a well-delineated 'oil droplet' reflex can be elicited. It is an annular black shadow that separates the central and peripheral areas of the cornea.
  • Fleischer's rings are epithelial iron deposits that are best seen with a cobalt blue filter during slit-lamp examination.
  • Vogt striae are vertical deep stromal lines seen using a slit-lamp.
  • The scissoring/yawning reflex can be elicited using a retinoscopy. It occurs when two bands of a light beam reflexed from the retina move like the blades of a pair of scissors.
  • Corneal topography and keratometry are also used for diagnosis.

Keratoconus means conical cornea. It is a progressive disorder and occurs due to central/paracentral thinning of the corneal stroma. This results in apical protrusion of the cornea and irregular astigmatism. The aetiology is not fully known and it may be seen associated with Down's, Ehlers-Danlos, and Marfan syndromes. Pathologically, the thinning and ectasia are due to abnormal production of mucopolysaccharide and collagen tissues.

Patients complain of defective vision due to progressive myopia and irregular astigmatism despite full correction with glasses. Complications such as acute hydrops can occur, where there is a rupture of the Descemet membrane and sudden influx of aqueous into the cornea. Treatment includes spectacles, rigid contact lenses, and corneal collagen cross-linking (CXL). CXL is done by instilling riboflavin drops to photosensitise the eye, after which ultraviolet type A exposure is given. This is said to stabilise or even reverse ectasia. LASIK is contraindicated in patients with keratoconus.

Related Pearl: Clinical findings in keratoconus

External signs:

  • Munson’s sign- V-shaped conformation of the lower lid produced by the ectatic cornea in downgaze 
  • Rizzuti’s sign- sharply focused conical beam of light near the nasal limbus, produced by lateral illumination of the cornea from the temporal side

Slit-lamp signs:

  • Vogt’s striae- fine vertical stress lines in the deep stroma, parallel to the steep axis of the cone. May disappear with external pressure on the globe.
  • Fleischer ring- deposition of iron in the epithelium in a ring shape at the base of the conical protrusion.
  • Corneal thinning- predominantly in the inferotemporal area.
  • Hydrops- an acute rupture in Descemet’s membrane causing imbibition of aqueous into the corneal stroma. It is a complication of long-standing keratoconus.
  • Prominent corneal nerves- increased visibility of the corneal nerve fibres.
  • Rupture in Bowman’s layer- irregular superficial opacities that develop due to breaks in Bowman’s layer.

Retroillumination signs:

  • Scissoring reflex- during retinoscopy, two bands of the light beam reflexed from the retina, moves like the blades of the pair of scissors, towards and away from each other. This sign is diagnostic of keratoconus.
  • Oil droplet sign (“Charleaux” sign)- dark reflex in the area of the cone on observation of cornea in dilated pupil by distant direct ophthalmoscopy.

questions.text: A man who is on an anti-glaucoma drug for the past 6 months comes for regular follow-up. During his review checkup, the following finding is observed. Which of the following drugs is most likely to cause this side effect?
questions.solution:
The image shows increased iris pigmentation and it is most likely to be the side effect of using topical prostaglandin (PGF2α) analogs like latanoprost.

Prostaglandin analogs such as latanoprost, travoprost, bimatoprost, tafluprost, and unoprostone are used as first-line medications in glaucoma. They reduce the intraocular pressure by increasing the uveoscleral outflow of aqueous humor.

Their side effects include increased and irreversible iris pigmentation, eyelash thickening, and conjunctival hyperemia. The use of prostaglandin analogs increases the likelihood of cystoid macular edema, especially in a pre-and post- cataract operation.

Other options:

Option A: Timolol is a topical non-selective beta-blocker used in glaucoma. Ocular adverse effects such as allergy and punctate keratitis can be seen. Systemic side effects like bradycardia and bronchospasm may be seen due to absorption through the nasolacrimal duct.

Option C: Pilocarpine is a miotic agent used in glaucoma. Local adverse effects such as miosis and induced myopia can be seen. Systemic symptoms such as bronchospasm and bradycardia may be rarely seen.

Option D: Dorzolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor and reduces intraocular pressure by reducing the aqueous humor formation. It causes stinging and a bitter taste.

questions.text:
Arrange the following layers of the retina starting from the outermost layer and ending with the innermost layer.

1. Pigment epithelium

2. Outer plexiform layer

3. Ganglion cell layer

4. Internal limiting membrane
questions.solution:
The sequence of arrangement of the retinal layers starting from the outermost and ending in the innermost layer is as follows:

1. Pigment epithelium

2. Outer plexiform layer

3. Ganglion cell layer

4. Internal limiting membrane

The retina is composed of 10 microscopic layers and is arranged as 2 distinctive components - pigment epithelium and neurosensory retina. They are as follows:

  1. Pigment epithelium is the outermost layer that is attached to the underlying choroid. It provides metabolic support to the neurosensory retina and acts as an antireflective layer. 
  2. Layers of rods and cones contain the outer segments of the photoreceptors cells. (rods and cones).
  3. External limiting membrane is a fenestrated membrane through which the processes of the rods and cones pass.
  4. Outer nuclear layer consists of the nuclei of rods and cones.
  5. Outer plexiform layer contains connections between the photoreceptor cells to the dendrites of bipolar and horizontal cells.
  6. Inner nuclear layer contains the cell bodies of bipolar, horizontal, and Muller's cells. Bipolar cells are first-order neurons of the visual pathway.
  7. Inner plexiform layer contains connections between bipolar cells and dendrites of ganglion cells.
  8. Ganglion cell layer contain ganglion cell bodies (second-order neurons).
  9. Nerve fiber layer contain ganglion cell axons which pass through lamina cribrosa to form the optic nerve. 
  10. Internal limiting membrane is the innermost layer and separates the retina from the vitreous.

questions.text: As a first-year ophthalmology resident, you come across a child with the following presentation. Which of the following disorders is it associated with?
