questions.text: A man, who had recent sinusitis,  comes with complaints of diplopia and ophthalmoplegia.  You note that there is left eye ptosis and acute bilateral proptosis. What likely complication is the patient presenting with?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of diplopia and ophthalmoplegia with ptosis and acute bilateral proptosis suggests the patient is presenting with the likely complication of cavernous sinus thrombosis (CST). 

Cavernous sinus thrombosis usually occurs as a complication of orbital cellulitis, preseptal cellulitis, sinusitis, otitis, or other infections in veins that communicate with the cavernous sinus.

The symptoms and signs are similar to orbital cellulitis (Option A). However, the differentiating features are:

Features Cavernous venous thrombosis Orbital cellulitis
Proptosis Initially unilateral,  then bilateral Usually unilateral
3rd, 4th and/or 6th nerve palsy Present Absent
Edema of mastoid region Pathognomonic of CST Absent 
Generalized symptoms Marked Mild

 

Magnetic resonance venography is the investigation of choice and shows an absence of flow in the thrombosed sinuses. CST is treated with aggressive intravenous antibiotics, analgesics, and anticoagulation. 

Other options: 

Option C: Panophthalmitis is also a differential diagnosis of CST. However, as in orbital cellulitis, proptosis is usually present unilaterally. Features of cranial nerve palsies are also not seen.

Option D: Preseptal cellulitis is the inflammation and edema of the ocular structures anterior to the orbital septum (it does not involve the orbit). Proptosis is absent and ocular movements are normal in this condition.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes with complaints of floaters and photopsia for the past 3 months. You note your senior using the following instrument to evaluate the patient. What method is being used?
questions.solution:
The method being used is indirect ophthalmoscopy. It is a type of ophthalmoscopy and is used for fundus examination. 

Fundus examination can be done using ophthalmoscopy or a slit-lamp biomicroscopy. Ophthalmoscopy is the method of assessing the interior of the eye by using an ophthalmoscope. There are 3 types of ophthalmoscopy, mainly indirect ophthalmoscopy, direct ophthalmoscopy, and distant direct ophthalmoscopy.

An indirect ophthalmoscope produces a real, inverted, and magnified image. It is essential for assessing retinal detachment and other peripheral retinal lesions. 

Advantages of  an indirect ophthalmoscope over a direct ophthalmoscope are:

Image Real, Inverted Virtual, Erect
Magnification  X~2.5   X 15
Area of the field in focus  Much larger (8 disc diameter) Small (2 disc diameter)
Examination through hazy media Possible Not possible
Depth perception Possible Not possible

Other options:

Option A: Slit-lamp biomicroscopy is used to scan the eye anteroposteriorly and horizontally.

Option D: Distant direct ophthalmoscopy is used to help recognize a detached retina, diagnose opacities in the refractive media, etc. It can be performed using a self-illuminated ophthalmoscope or a simple plain mirror with a hole at its center.

questions.text: An infant is brought with complaints of constant epiphora with mucopurulent discharge and a non-pulsatile swelling as shown in the image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given presentation of epiphora and a non-pulsatile swelling (as shown in the image) in an infant is suggestive of congenital dacryocystitis.

Congenital dacrocystitis is the chronic inflammation of the lacrimal sac. It occurs due to the stasis of secretions which in turn is due to congenital blockage of the nasolacrimal duct. Incomplete canalization of the valve of Hasner is the most common cause.

Regurgitation test (applying pressure over the lacrimal sac causes regurgitation of mucopurulent discharge from the lower punctum) is usually positive.

The treatment plan is decided according to the age at which the baby is brought. Massaging over the lacrimal sac and topical antibiotics are used as the mainstay of treatment. Probing of the nasolacrimal duct with Bowman's probe is done if it persists even at 6 months of age. Balloon catheter dilatation is done if probing fails. If these methods fail, intubation with a silicone tube is done where the tube is kept in the nasolacrimal duct for six months. If even this intervention fails, dacryocystorhinostomy is done after 4 years of age. 

 Other options:

Option A: Anterior encephalocele is a pulsatile medial canthal swelling caused by the herniation of intracranial content through a congenital defect of the base of the skull.

Option C: Syringomas are benign proliferations of eccrine sweat glands and are noted as multiple small papules on the eyelid. 

Option D: Chalazion is a non-suppurative, painless swelling of the Meibomian gland in the eyelid.

The instrument in the above image is a Humphrey visual field analyzer. It is an automated perimeter. They are computer-assisted machines that test visual fields by the static method.

Perimetry is the procedure of estimating the extent of the visual fields.

There are 2 types of perimetry: kinetic and static perimetry. In kinetic perimetry, a target of given luminance is moved from a non-seeing area in the periphery towards the center where it is perceived. In the static method, the location of a stimulus remains fixed, with the intensity increased until it is seen by the subject (threshold is reached) or decreased until it is no longer detected.

Charting of the visual fields is useful in the diagnosis of many disease conditions such as glaucoma, neurological disorders, and retinal diseases (e.g. retinitis pigmentosa) as well as following laser treatment of diabetic retinopathy.

questions.text: A  patient comes with a history of difficulty in closing his eyes for the past 1 month. On examination, you note lid retraction in the right eye as shown below. What did you note on examination?
questions.solution:
The examination finding and image show Dalrymple's sign.

It is the commonest and earliest sign of Grave's ophthalmopathy. Here there is lid retraction and scleral show. The scleral show occurs due to the lid margin being level with or above the superior limbus, causing the upper sclera to become visible. The cause of lid retraction is thought to be the overactivity of levator aponeurosis and Müller muscle.

Grave's disease is an autoimmune disorder that results in hyperthyroidism. In this condition, autoantibodies bind to thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) receptors and stimulate the secretion of thyroid hormone. 

Thyroid ophthalmopathy or thyroid eye disease can be seen in Graves disease or even in euthyroid/hypothyroid patients. Women and smokers are at higher risk of developing Grave's ophthalmopathy (otherwise known as thyroid eye disease). 

Thyroid function tests and a thyroid autoantibody assay should be done to assess thyroid hormone status. 

Control of hyperthyroidism is effective in management. Injecting botulinum toxin to levator aponeurosis and Müller muscle may be done as a temporary measure.

The other options are all signs associated with Grave's disease but do not correlate with the given image.

questions.text: A 65-year-old  female patient presented with progressive painless loss of vision. A fundus picture of the patient is given below. What could be the probable finding?
questions.solution:
The above fundal image shows small, discrete yellowish, waxy areas with crenated margins that are suggestive of hard exudates, seen in diabetic retinopathy.

Hard exudates are leaked lipoproteins and lipid-filled macrophages that form due to chronic localized edema. They are commonly seen in the macular area and occur in the outer plexiform layer of the retina. 

Other common causes of hard exudates include hypertensive retinopathy, Coats’ disease, and circinate retinopathy.

Other options:

Option A: Cotton wool spots (old name soft exudates) appear as whitish fluffy spots with indistinct margins that show areas of nerve fiber infarction.

Common causes are hypertensive retinopathy, toxaemic retinopathy of pregnancy, diabetic retinopathy, anemias, and collagen disorders like discoid lupus erythematosus, polyarteritis nodosa, and scleroderma.

The image below shows a fundus picture with cotton wool spots

 

Option C: Roth spots, shown below, are retinal hemorrhages with white centers that are composed of coagulated fibrin.

They are seen in acute leukemia, bacteremia (subacute bacterial endocarditis), diabetes, hypertension, and anemia.

 

Option D: Cherry red spot, shown below, is seen in central retinal artery occlusion, where the vascular choroid shines through the thin foveal retina, when compared to the surrounding pale retina.

Related Pearl: Hypertensive retinopathy

Hypertensive retinopathy describes the fundus changes that occur in a patient with systemic hypertension. It is graded as follows:

  • Grade 1 - Mild generalized retinal arteriolar narrowing
  • Grade 2 - Focal arteriolar narrowing and deflection of veins at AV crossings (Salu's sign).
  • Grade 3 - Grade 2 changes with the following:
    • Copper-wiring of arterioles
    • Cotton wool spots, retinal hemorrhages (dot, blot, flame) or exudates (chronic retinal edema)
    • Bonnet’s sign: Banking of veins distal to arteriovenous crossings
    • Gunn’s sign: Tapering of veins on either side of the arteriovenous crossings 
      Macular star (Deposition of hard exudates around the fovea) may be present. 
  • Grade 4 - Severe grade 3 changes with optic disc swelling or papilledema (a marker of malignant hypertension) and silver-wiring of arterioles.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the casualty after an accident. Secondary survey shows a bruised left eye. The hanging drop sign is seen on CT coronal section of the orbit.  Which of the following clinical features is seen associated with this CT finding?
questions.solution:
The clinical feature associated with the CT finding of hanging drop/tear-drop sign is numbness in the infraorbital region. This is noted in an orbital blowout fracture where orbital contents herniate through the floor of the orbit into the maxillary antrum. 

Blow-out orbital fractures are caused by trauma to the orbit by a large, rounded object, e.g cricket ball, a human fist, etc. This force can cause the displacement of the eyeball backward and an increase in intraorbital pressure. This leads to fracturing at the weakest point of the orbital wall (orbital floor and sometimes medial wall).  

Other options:

Option A: Iridodialysis is seen in traumatic closed globe injury. Here, the iris detaches from the ciliary body resulting in a D-shaped pupil and a peripheral black biconvex area. Iridodialysis is not associated with the characteristic hanging drop pattern of orbital blowout fracture.

Option B: Keratic precipitates are the characteristic clinical feature in anterior uveitis. 

Option D: Pulsatile proptosis is seen in carotid-cavernous fistula. The classical triad is proptosis, chemosis, and bruit.
